Kirkwood-Buff Integral Analysis (picmol.kbi)¶

class picmol.kbi.KBI(prj_path: str, pure_component_path: str, rdf_dir: str = 'rdf_files', kbi_method: str = 'adj', rkbi_min=0.75, kbi_fig_dirname: str = 'kbi_analysis', avg_start_time=100, avg_end_time=None, solute_mol=None, geom_mean_pairs=[])[source]¶

Class for calculating Kirkwood-Buff Integrals from radial distribution functions in a GROMACS project.

Parameters:

  • prj_path (str) – absolute path to project directory; contains subdirectories containing systems as a function of composition

  • pure_component_path (str) – absolute path to pure component directory; contains subdirectories of molecules at a given temperature

  • rdf_dir (str, optional) – directory name where RDF files are located in each system directory, default is rdf_files

  • kbi_method (str, optional) –

    correction method to apply to correlation function, default is adj

    • 'raw': no correction

    • 'adj': correcting for tail of RDF \(\neq\) 1 at large r

    • 'gv': correcting the number densities to account for excess/depletion, introduced by Ganguly and Van der Vegt

    • 'kgv': applying a damping function introduced by Kruger to the correction function by Ganguly and Van der Vegt

  • rkbi_min (float or dict, optional) – fraction of r; lower bound for extrapolation to the thermodynamic limit, default is 0.75. float will be applied to all systems and dict uses systems as keys with corresponding float values.

  • kbi_fig_dirname (str, optional) – directory name for results from KBI analysis, default is kbi_analysis

  • avg_start_time (float, optional) – start time (ns) for property (temperature, volume, enthalpy) analysis from .edr file, default is 100

  • avg_end_time – end time (ns) for property (temperature, volume, enthalpy) analysis from .edr file, default is end of trajectory

  • solute_mol (str) – molecule name in .top file corresponding to molecule used to sort systems

  • geom_mean_pairs (list[list[str]], optional) – pairs of molecules for taking the geometric mean of, default is empty list

Run KBI analysis and calculate activity coefficients and Gibbs thermodynamic properties

kbi_npt(r, g, r_lo, r_hi, avg, sys_num, mol_i, mol_j)[source]¶

For a given radial distribution function, calculate KBI from r_lo to r_hi by applying a correction to the correlation function.

The correlation function, \(h_{ij}(r)\), is not corrected when kbi_method = ‘raw’.

\[h_{ij}(r) = g_{ij}^{NpT}(r) - 1\]

For the kbi_method = ‘adj’ correlation function correction, the excess/depletion of molecule j around molecule i in a system with fixed number of components is adjusted based on the limiting behavior of the radial distribution function tail at large r.

\[h_{ij}^{adj}(r) = g_{ij}^{NpT}(r) - \text{avg}\]

Ganguly and Van der Vegt (2013) introduced a correction to the radial distribution function (kbi_method = ‘gv’) to correct the number of molecules of type j around molecules of type i, where \(N_j\) is the number of molecules of type j, \(\Delta N_{ij}\) is the number of molecules of type j around molecule i in radius of shell dr, and \(V\) is the volume of simulation box.

\[h_{ij}^{gv}(r) = g_{ij}^{NpT}(r) \left(\frac{N_j\left(1 - \frac{4/3 \pi r^3}{V} \right)}{N_j \left(1 - \frac{4/3 \pi r^3}{V} \right) - \Delta N_{ij} - \delta_{ij}} \right) - 1\]
\[\Delta N_{ij} = \int_0^R 4 \pi r^2 \rho_j \left(g_{ij}^{NpT}(r) - 1\right) dr\]

Dawass and Krüger et al. (2019) applied a damping function for hyperspheres geometry (kbi_method = ‘kgv’) to the Ganguly and Van der Vegt correction to force limiting behavior of correlation function at large r to be 1.

\[h_{ij}^{kgv}(r) = h_{ij}^{gv} \left(1 - \frac{3r}{2R} + \frac{r^3}{2r^3} \right)\]

KBI calculations for finite size R (\(G_{ij}^R\)), from correlation functions.

\[G_{ij}^R = \int_0^R 4 \pi r^2 h_{ij}(r) dr\]
Parameters:

  • r (numpy.ndarray) – distance (nm) between two molecule types in radial distribution function

  • g (numpy.ndarray) – radial distribution function for two molecule types as a function of r

  • r_lo (float) – minimum r (nm) to evaluate integral over

  • r_hi (float) – maximum r (nm) to evaluate integral over

  • avg (float) – average value of \(g_{ij}(r)\) at large r, i.e., tail of radial distribution function

  • sys_num (int) – system index

  • mol_i (str) – molecule id in .top file for i in \(g_{ij}(r)\)

  • mol_j (str) – molecule id in .top file for j in \(g_{ij}(r)\)

Returns:

KBI in units of nm3 and cm3/mol.

Return type:

tuple[float, float]

kbi_thermo_limit(L, rkbi, min_L_idx)[source]¶

Extrapolate finite volume KBI to the thermodynamic limit as introduced by Simon and Krüger et al. (2022).

\[\lambda G_{ij}^R = \lambda G_{ij}^{\infty} + F_{ij}^{\infty}\]
Parameters:

  • L (numpy.ndarray) – fraction of the linear dimension of the box volume

  • rkbi (numpy.ndarray) – KBI as a function of r in RDF, i.e., running KBI

  • min_L_idx (int) – lower bound index of L for extrapolation

Returns:

list containing \(G_{ij}^{\infty}\) and \(F_{ij}^{\infty}\)

Return type:

list[float, float]

property z¶

Mole fraction array (\(\mathbf{z}\)) with elements, \(x_i\).

\[x_i = \frac{N_i}{\sum_j N_j}\]
Returns:

mole fraction array, with shape (len(systems), n)

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

property v¶

Volume fraction array (\(\mathbf{v}\)) with elements, \(\phi_i\) where \(V_i\) is the molar volume of molecule of type i.

\[\phi_i = \frac{x_i V_i}{\sum_j x_j V_j}\]
Returns:

volume fraction array, with shape (len(systems), n)

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

G_matrix()[source]¶

Construct a symmetric matrix (\(\mathbf{G}\)) of KBI values in the thermodynamic limit (nm3) between molecules of type i and j with elements, \(\mathbf{G}_{ij} = \mathbf{G}_{ji}\).

\[\begin{split}\mathbf{G} = \begin{bmatrix} G_{11}^\infty & G_{12}^\infty & \cdots & G_{1n}^\infty \\ G_{21}^\infty & G_{22}^\infty & \cdots & G_{2n}^\infty \\ \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ G_{n1}^\infty & G_{n2}^\infty & \cdots & G_{nn}^\infty \\ \end{bmatrix}\end{split}\]
Returns:

array of KBI values for each pairwise interaction, with shape (len(systems), n, n)

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

B_matrix()[source]¶

Construct a symmetric matrix (\(\mathbf{B}\)) of number fluctuations from KBI values in \(\mathbf{G}\), with elements \(\mathbf{B}_{ij}\).

\[\mathbf{B}_{ij} = \rho_i \rho_j \mathbf{G}_{ij} + \rho_i \delta_{ij}\]
\[\begin{split}\mathbf{B} = \begin{bmatrix} \rho_1^2 \mathbf{G}_{11} + \rho_1 & \rho_1 \rho_2 \mathbf{G}_{12} & \cdots & \rho_1 \rho_n \mathbf{G}_{1n} \\ \rho_1 \rho_2 \mathbf{G}_{21} & \rho_2^2 \mathbf{G}_{22} + \rho_2 & \cdots & \rho_2 \rho_n \mathbf{G}_{2n} \\ \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ \rho_1 \rho_n \mathbf{G}_{n1} & \rho_2 \rho_n \mathbf{G}_{n2} & \cdots & \rho_n^2 \mathbf{G}_{nn} + \rho_n \\ \end{bmatrix}\end{split}\]
Returns:

array with shape (len(systems), n, n)

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

cofactors_Bij()[source]¶

Get the cofactors of \(\mathbf{B}\), where elements are defined by \(\mathbf{B}^{ij}\).

\[\mathbf{B}^{ij} = \left(|\mathbf{B}| \mathbf{B}^{-1}\right)_{ij}\]
Returns:

cofactor matrix with shape (len(systems), n, n)

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

dmu_dN()[source]¶

Calculate the derivative of the chemical potential of component i with respect to the number of molecules of component j in the NpT ensemble.

\[\left(\frac{\partial \mu_i}{\partial N_j}\right)_{N, p, T} = \frac{k_bT}{\left<V\right> |\mathbf{B}|}\left(\frac{\sum_{a=1}^N\sum_{b=1}^N \rho_a\rho_b\left|\mathbf{B}^{ij}\mathbf{B}^{ab}-\mathbf{B}^{ai}\mathbf{B}^{bj}\right|}{\sum_{a=1}^N\sum_{b=1}^N \rho_a\rho_b \mathbf{B}^{ab}}\right)\]
Returns:

array of shape (len(systems), n, n)

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

dmu_dxs()[source]¶

Convert the chemical potential derivative with respect to molecule number to the mole fraction basis.

\[\left(\frac{\partial \mu_i}{\partial x_j}\right) = N \left(\frac{\partial \mu_i}{\partial N_j} - \frac{\partial \mu_i}{\partial N_n}\right)\]
Returns:

array of shape (len(systems), n-1, n-1)

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

dlngamma_dxs()[source]¶

Calculate the derivative of the natural logarithm of the activity coefficient of component i with respect to its mole fraction.

\[\frac{\partial \ln{\gamma_i}}{\partial x_i} = \frac{1}{k_BT} \frac{\partial \mu_i}{\partial x_i} - \frac{1}{x_i}\]
Returns:

array of shape (len(systems), n)

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

gammas()[source]¶

Numerical integration of activity coefficient derivatives to obtain activity coefficients.

\[\ln{\gamma_i}(x_i) = \int_{a_0}^{x_i} \left(\frac{\partial \ln{\gamma_i}}{\partial x_i}\right) dx_i \approx \sum_{a=a_0}^{x_i} \frac{\Delta x}{2} \left[\left(\frac{\partial \ln{\gamma_i}}{\partial x_i}\right)_{a} + \left(\frac{\partial \ln{\gamma_i}}{\partial x_i}\right)_{a \pm \Delta x}\right]\]

The integral is approximated by a summation using the trapezoidal rule, where the upper limit of summation is \(x_i\) and the initial condition (or reference state) is \(a_0\). Note that the term \(a \pm \Delta x\) behaves differently based on the value of \(a_0\): if \(a_0 = 1\) (pure component reference state), it becomes \(a - \Delta x\), and if \(a_0 = 0\) (infinite dilution reference state), it becomes \(a + \Delta x\).

Returns:

array of activity coefficients as a function of composition for each component

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

GE()[source]¶

Excess Gibbs energy.

\[G^E = RT\sum_{i=1}^{n} x_i \ln{\gamma_i}\]
Returns:

array for excess Gibbs energy as a function of composition

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

GM()[source]¶

Gibbs mixing free energy.

\[\Delta G_{mix} = RT\sum_{i=1}^{n} x_i \ln{\left(\gamma_i x_i\right)}\]
Returns:

array for Gibbs mixing free energy as a function of composition

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

Hmix()[source]¶

Mixing enthalpy from molecular simulation.

\[\Delta H_{mix} = H - \sum_{i=1}^{n} x_i H_{i}^{pc}\]

where:

  • \(H\) is the enthalpy for a simulation at a given composition and \(H_i^{pc}\) is the pure component enthalpy for molecule of type i.

Returns:

array for enthalpy of mixing as a function of composition

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

SE()[source]¶

Excess entropy from Gibbs excess property relations.

\[S^E = \frac{\Delta H_{mix} - G^E}{T}\]
Returns:

array for excess entropy as a function of composition

Return type:

numpy.ndarray
